revision.comment: talk page genfixes to aid tagging bots using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (10258)
revision.text: {{Talk header}} {{ITN talk|17 March|2011}} {{WikiProject Military history|class=Start | |B-Class-1=yes |B-Class-2=yes |B-Class-3=yes |B-Class-4=yes |B-Class-5=yes |South-Asian-task-force=yes|US-task-force=yes|Aviation-task-force=yes}} {{WikiProject Pakistan|class=Start|importance=Low}} == largest drone strikes == BBC's Ilyas Khan seems to have it wrong this time. [[23 June 2009 Makeen airstrike]] killed >60 and happened in 2009.--[[User:Wikireader41|Wikireader41]] ([[User talk:Wikireader41|talk]]) 19:47, 17 March 2011 (UTC) == Type of drone == The note about a [[Predator drone]] being involved in the attacks was [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Datta_Khel_airstrike&action=historysubmit&diff=419373009&oldid=419372767 removed] with the comment "I cannot find any reliable source that says this was the drone used; the article on these drone attacks say that another drone has been used in recent times." According to the [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/8388295/Drone-attack-kills-38.html Telegraph], "militants were killed by US Predator drones," which was the source I used (and then forgot to cite, oops) for the claim. I don't want to add the bit right back in, because I haven't actually been able to find another source, but I'd appreciate thoughts. [[User:C628|C628]] ([[User talk:C628|talk]]) 22:58, 17 March 2011 (UTC) :I don't dispute that it was a U.S. predator drone. My point was that it's unclear whether it was the MQ-1 predator drone that was pictured or the MQ-9 Reaper that the [[Drone attacks in Pakistan]] article says has been used more recently. I cannot find a reliable source that says what type of drone it was. I edited the intro [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Datta_Khel_airstrike&action=historysubmit&diff=419376616&oldid=419373009] to remove any doubt that this was an American airstrike.--[[User:Chaser|Chaser]] ([[User talk:Chaser|talk]]) 23:06, 17 March 2011 (UTC) :: it would be hard to tell which exact drone ( MQ-1 or MQ-9) was used since CIA/US does not provide details on the type of drone or the weapons used.--[[User:Wikireader41|Wikireader41]] ([[User talk:Wikireader41|talk]]) 00:02, 18 March 2011 (UTC) == POV? == The term ''blood money'' is used in the opening paragraph. Is this not a loaded term? Could the author just say that money was paid? —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/83.70.133.9|83.70.133.9]] ([[User talk:83.70.133.9|talk]]) 14:13, 19 March 2011 (UTC) :Perhaps. My guess is it was added because that's the term the main article on the incident ([[Raymond Allen Davis incident]]) uses. Don't see any reason it couldn't be removed if you find it objectionable. [[User:C628|C628]] ([[User talk:C628|talk]]) 14:44, 19 March 2011 (UTC) :In fact, I've swapped the term ''[[diyya]]'' for blood money, as it's both more neutral and more precise. [[User:C628|C628]] ([[User talk:C628|talk]]) 14:48, 19 March 2011 (UTC) No my point was that it is editorialising - this is an encylopedia. We are not analysing the event. —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/83.70.133.9|83.70.133.9]] ([[User talk:83.70.133.9|talk]]) 08:21, 24 March 2011 (UTC) :The articles, [[diyya]] and [[Blood money (term)]] don't seem to indicate it's a loaded term.-[[User:Rdavi404|RDavi404]] ([[User talk:Rdavi404|talk]]) 13:29, 24 March 2011 (UTC) ::Blood money I could see as perhaps editorializing, but certainly not diyya, that's the exact term for what happened and I don't see how that comes across as analysis. [[User:C628|C628]] ([[User talk:C628|talk]]) 14:30, 24 March 2011 (UTC)
